raw_comment:
What I notice is how the percentage of young people who reach out to their parents at least once a day or few days a week is particularly dominated by women. Whether its sending texts, phone or video-chat, or a visit in person, women always tend to do so more then men and some by a large margin. What I wonder is if the percentages have increased or decreased over time by both men and women of how often they reach out to their parents.  Also if visiting in person decreased when more kids started getting phones. What's going on in this graph is it is trying to show the different ways young people will reach out to their parents, characterizing it by gender, and showing the percentage difference between men and women and how men truly do not seem to reach out as much as women. This relates to my community because I have siblings and I think my sister, who is out of the house, and I reach out more then my brother does. We also would tend to see them in person more rather then call or text. 
Catchy headline: "Incoming call, it's your parents! Accept or Decline?"
ace_sentences: I notice a graph.
The graph shows percentages of young people who contact their parents at least once a day or a few days a week.
In the graph, women dominate these percentages.
Young people can contact their parents by text message.
Young people can contact their parents by phone call.
Young people can contact their parents by video chat.
Young people can contact their parents by an in-person visit.
Women tend to contact their parents more than men.
In some cases, women contact their parents much more than men.
I wonder whether these percentages have increased over time.
I wonder whether these percentages have decreased over time.
I wonder whether the change over time is different for men and women.
I wonder whether in-person visits decreased when more children got phones.
The graph compares different ways of contacting parents.
The graph characterizes the data by gender.
The graph shows the percentage difference between men and women.
Men do not seem to contact their parents as much as women.
This relates to my community.
I have siblings.
I have a sister.
My sister is out of the house.
My brother contacts our parents.
My sister contacts our parents more than my brother contacts our parents.
I contact our parents more than my brother contacts our parents.
My sister and I tend to see our parents in person more than we call our parents.
My sister and I tend to see our parents in person more than we text our parents.
The headline is: Incoming call, it is your parents! Accept or Decline?
